Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Situation2: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Story:
I was halfway through scrubbing the kitchen floor when my phone buzzed urgently. My partner’s voice echoed from the living room, “Can you help me move the sofa? The guests will be here in two hours.” I glanced at the clock, feeling the pressure mount. The house was still a mess—dishes piled up, laundry unfolded, and the guest room needed fresh sheets. I knew how much it meant to my spouse that everything looked perfect for the relatives’ visit.

But then, another call came in—this time from the factory. The supervisor’s voice was tense: “The main production unit is down again. We’re losing time. Can you come in right away?” I could picture the blinking red lights, the frustrated operators, and the mounting costs with every minute the line stayed silent. They needed me to diagnose the sensor errors, to get things running before the backlog became unmanageable.

I stood in the hallway, mop in one hand, phone in the other, heart pounding. Both worlds demanded all of me, right now. I felt torn, knowing that no matter what I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
